revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox video game |title=Black Knight Sword |image=Black Knight Sword cover.jpg |developer=[[Grasshopper Manufacture]]
[[Digital Reality]] |engine= [[Unreal Engine 3]] |publisher=[[D3 Publisher]] |platforms=[[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]] |released={{vgrelease|NA|December 11, 2012 (PS3)|NA|December 12, 2012 (X360)|EU|December 12, 2012|AU|December 12, 2012 (X360)|JP|January 10, 2013}} |director=Ren Yamazaki |designer=Ren Yamazaki |producer=Shuji Ishikawa |writer=[[Goichi Suda]]
Ren Yamazaki |composer=[[Akira Yamaoka]] |genre=[[Action game|Action]], [[Platform game|platformer]], [[Metroidvania]]{{cite web | url = http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2011/09/12/grasshoppers-black-knight-sword-demoed-in-all-new-trailer/ | title = Grasshopper’s Black Knight Sword Demoed in All-New Trailer | first = Alex | last = Osborn | date = September 12, 2011 | website = PlayStation LifeStyle | publisher = [[CraveOnline]] | accessdate = July 14, 2016 | quote = "It looks like Suda51 and his team over at Grasshopper Manufacture are taking a stab at a side scrolling “Metroidvania” game of their own with ''Black Knight Sword''."}} |modes=[[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |artist = Kazuyuki Kurashima}} {{nihongo|'''''Black Knight Sword'''''|ブラック・ナイト・ソード|Burakku Naito Sōdo}} is a [[side-scrolling]] action platformer game co-developed by [[Grasshopper Manufacture]] and [[Digital Reality]]. It was released in North America on the [[PlayStation 3]] via the [[PlayStation Network]] on December 11, 2012 and on [[Xbox 360]] via [[Xbox Live Arcade]] on December 12, 2012. ==Gameplay== [[File:Black Knight Sword screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|''Black Knight Sword'' features a unique [[Kamishibai]] art style.]] ''Black Knight Sword'' plays is a side-scrolling action game. Players control a character who takes on the identity of the Black Knight and his sword on their quest to defeat the White Princess. The game features a theater styled backdrop whereupon the character remains static as the backdrops change place to give the player a feeling of movement. {{cite web | url = https://www.engadget.com/2011/08/17/grasshopper-and-digital-reality-reveal-black-knight-sword-for/ | title = Grasshopper and Digital Reality reveal 'Black Knight Sword' for PSN and XBLA | first = JC | last = Fletcher | date = August 17, 2011 | website = [[Engadget]] ([[Joystiq]]) | publisher = [[Oath Inc.]] | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} The player is armed with a magical sword used to dispatch foes, and the game also features elements of platforming. Hearts can be collected from fallen enemies, which in turn can be used in various in-game shops to purchase equipment and upgrades.{{cite web | url = https://www.xboxachievements.com/news/news-11386-Black-Knight-Sword-Hands-On-Preview-%E2%80%93--Tis-But-a-Scratch-.html | title = Black Knight Sword Hands-On Preview – 'Tis But a Scratch! | first = Richard | last = Walker | date = April 6, 2012 | website = Xbox Achievements | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} ==Plot== The game begins with a [[narrator]] stating "The wormwood sways back and forth, embracing the wind", as [[stage curtain]]s open to reveal the set of a [[Play (theatre)|play]], and the [[player character]], Grahame Wormwood, having committed [[suicide]] by hanging himself in an empty bedroom. He sways back and forth to free himself from the [[noose]] around his neck, and what lies in front of him on the floor is a black suit of armor impaled with a sword, and a small, doll-like female character, known as Black Hellebore hovering above it. Black Hellebore then seems to inhabit the sword by phasing inside of it, and Grahame pulls the sword from the suit of armor. The black suit of armor then binds itself to Wormwood, as the play continues with Wormwood (now as the Black Knight), with the help of Black Hellebore, progressing through [[stage set]]s filled with hostile creatures, whom are often disembodied heads, other grotesque monstrosities, and [[wild animals]]. The [[stage play]] is separated into and presented in 5 acts, with each act prefacing itself with [[fairy tale]]-like scenarios involving animals and their deaths. The animals in these stories serve as each act's finale. For example, one tale tells of a spider that saved a princess from entrapment, only to have been killed by her unassuming father upon her return. This spider then serves as the act's finale, with the Black Knight engaging it in battle. The narrator often tells the audience to "beware" before these encounters occur, and applauds the Black Knight when he defeats these creatures. This theme of Wormwood having to make his way past animals with seemingly unfortunate pasts continues until the play reaches its final act, which is prefaced with a story about two constantly bickering sisters. The story states that God disapproved of their arguing so much that He trapped the two inside of their own fairy tale, where they could bicker for the rest of eternity. As the Black Knight makes his way to act 5's finale, the narrator (seemingly addressing the Black Knight himself) starts to question if he even remembers all the ones he's killed and loved. As color progressively fades from the set, the narrator continues to state that if they are forgotten, then there is "nothing left." The Black Knight then finds himself standing in front of the hanged Grahame Wormwood, whom he cuts from his noose with his sword. The room then fills with white flowers as a White Princess appears. The Black Knight taunts the Princess and engages her in battle. The White Princess appears ethereal as she floats around, [[telepathically]] chucking disembodied heads at the Black Knight and growing to an inhuman size. She then begins throwing eggs at the Black Knight which hatch into the disembodied heads and grotesque creatures he's already been facing throughout the play, where it's revealed that the White Princess was in control of these creatures all along. After The Black Knight defeats the White Princess (with invaluable help from Black Hellebore), her body dissipates and leaves a white suit of armor and white sword behind, as a small, white, doll-like character emerges; White Hellebore. Black Hellebore and White Hellebore are the two sisters mentioned in the prefacing tale, and true to the story, they start fighting each other as the Black Knight watches on. White Hellebore then animates the white suit of armor, and the White Knight appears and begins to attack the Black Knight. The game concludes with a battle between the Black Knight and the White Knight on a stage set that's looking down at the Earth. After the White Knight and White Hellebore are defeated, the Black Knight and Black Hellebore then return to the initial bedroom set of the play, passing all of the previous sets along the way. Before entering the room, Black Hellebore removes herself from the sword the Black Knight is holding and flies away, as the sword and the armor dissipate completely, with Wormwood freed from the armor's binding. Wormwood then enters the bedroom and once again hangs himself. The narrator then reiterates the line "The Wormwood sways back and forth, embracing the wind," and adds "one day, the fields themselves will wither and fade. The wormwood forgotten by all," as the stage curtains close and the play comes to an end. ==Development== ''Black Knight Sword'' was announced on August 17, 2011 at [[Gamescom]]. It was developed jointly by Grasshopper Manufacture and Digital Reality. The game is one of two collaborations between the two teams, the other being ''[[Sine Mora]]'', with Digital Reality publishing the game. In response to an interviewer's question regarding the collaboration, Director of Publishing Balázs Horváth simply stated that the two teams "both know what makes a good game."{{cite web | url = http://www.xblafans.com/wielding-the-black-knights-sword-at-pax-east-44324.html | title = Wielding the Black Knight’s sword at PAX East | first = Nick | last = Santalego | date = April 8, 2012 | website = XBLAFans | accessdate = April 14, 2012}} A preview version was playable at [[Penny Arcade Expo]] (PAX) Prime 2011.{{cite web | url = http://shogungamer.com/news/13260/sine-mora-exclusive-developer-interview | title = Sine Mora Exclusive Developer Interview | first = Ian | last = Fisher | date = February 1, 2012 | website = Shogun Gamer | publisher = Shogun Gamer Media Inc. | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120204163150/http://shogungamer.com/news/13260/sine-mora-exclusive-developer-interview | archivedate = February 4, 2012 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} It was also shown with a playable demo at PAX East 2012 in Boston, Massachusetts. Digital Reality has described the game as "[[Monty Python]] meets Czech animation meets Japanese [[Kamishibai|paper theater]]."{{cite web | url = http://www.gameinformer.com/games/black_knight_sword/b/ps3/archive/2011/08/19/grasshopper-brings-its-weirdness-to-dlgs.aspx | title = Black Knight Sword (Preview): Grasshopper Brings Its Weirdness To DLGs | first = Jeff | last = Cork | date = August 19, 2011 | website = [[Game Informer]] | publisher = [[GameStop]] | accessdate = April 3, 2012}} Composer [[Akira Yamaoka]] called the game "a throwback to the old-school classic side-scrolling action games."{{cite web | url = http://www.shacknews.com/article/69780/black-knight-sword-is-grasshoppers-next-psn-and-xbla | title = Black Knight Sword announced for XBLA and PSN by Grasshopper Manufacture | first = Andrew | last = Yoon | date = August 17, 2011 | website = [[Shacknews]] | accessdate = April 3, 2012}} During early previews the game drew comparisons from critics to the ''[[Mega Man]]'', ''[[Strider (arcade game)|Strider]]'' and ''[[Castlevania]]'' series.{{cite web | url = https://www.destructoid.com/preview-black-knight-sword-209665.phtml | title = Preview: Black Knight Sword | first = Maurice | last = Tan | date = August 24, 2011 | website = [[Destructoid]] | publisher = Enthusiast Gaming | accessdate = April 3, 2012}}{{cite web | url = https://www.psu.com/news/black-knight-sword-preview/ | title = Black Knight Sword preview | first = Robert | last = Zwetsloot | date = September 1, 2011 | website = [[PSU.com]] | publisher = The Bishop Way Inc. | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | PS3 = true | X360 = true | na = true | Destruct_PS3 = 6.5/10{{cite web | url = https://www.destructoid.com/review-black-knight-sword-240426.phtml | title = Review: Black Knight Sword (PS3) | first = Chris | last = Carter | date = December 13, 2012 | website = Destructoid | publisher = Enthusiast Gaming | accessdate = June 5, 2018}} | EGM_PS3 = 5/10{{cite web | url = http://www.egmnow.com/articles/reviews/egm-review-black-knight-sword/ | title = EGM Review: Black Knight Sword (PS3) | first = Mollie L. | last = Patterson | date = December 14, 2012 | website = [[Electronic Gaming Monthly|EGMNow]] | publisher = EGM Media, LLC | accessdate = June 5, 2018}} | EuroG_X360 = 6/10{{cite web | url = https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-01-03-black-knight-sword-review | title = Black Knight Sword review (Xbox 360) | first = Simon | last = Parkin | date = January 3, 2013 | website = [[Eurogamer]] | publisher = Gamer Network}} | GameRev_PS3 = {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite web | url = http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/58363-black-knight-sword-review | title = Black Knight Sword Review (PS3) | first = Daniel R. | last = Bischoff | date = December 14, 2012 | website = [[Game Revolution]] | publisher = CraveOnline | accessdate = June 5, 2018}} | GSpot_PS3 = 7/10{{cite web | url = https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/black-knight-sword-review/1900-6401805/ | title = Black Knight Sword Review (PS3) | first = Peter | last = Brown | date = December 20, 2012 | website = [[GameSpot]] | publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} | GT_PS3 = 5.7/10{{cite web | url = http://www.gametrailers.com/reviews/51u6q8/black-knight-sword-review | title = Black Knight Sword - Review (PS3) | date = January 4, 2013 | website = [[GameTrailers]] | publisher = [[Viacom]] | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130108225129/http://www.gametrailers.com/reviews/51u6q8/black-knight-sword-review | archivedate = January 8, 2013 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = June 5, 2018}} | GameZone_PS3 = 6/10{{cite web | url = https://www.gamezone.com/reviews/review-black-knight-sword-is-one-of-the-prettiest-games-of-the-year-but-sadly-nothing-more/ | title = Review: Black Knight Sword is one of the prettiest games of the year but sadly nothing more (PS3) | first = David | last = Sanchez | date = December 25, 2012 | website = GameZone | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130216095038/http://www.gamezone.com/products/black-knight-sword/reviews/review-black-knight-sword-is-one-of-the-prettiest-games-of-the-year-but-sadly-nothing-more | archivedate = February 16, 2013 | deadurl = no | accessdate = June 5, 2018}} | IGN_PS3 = 6.9/10{{cite web | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/12/14/black-knight-sword-review | title = Black Knight Sword Review | first = Nathan | last = Meunier | date = December 13, 2012 | website = [[IGN]] | publisher = [[Ziff Davis]] | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} | IGN_X360 = 6.9/10 | Joystiq_PS3 = {{Rating|2.5|5}}{{cite web | url = https://www.engadget.com/2012/12/14/black-knight-sword-review/ | title = Black Knight Sword review: All flash, no flesh | first = Jordan | last = Mallory | date = December 14, 2012 | website = Engadget (Joystiq) | publisher = Oath Inc.}} | OXM_X360 = 7/10{{cite magazine | url = http://www.oxmonline.com/black-knight-sword-review | title = Black Knight Sword review | first = Cameron | last = Lewis | date = November 2012 | page = 77 | magazine = [[Official Xbox Magazine]] | publisher = [[Future US]] | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121216034710/http://www.oxmonline.com/black-knight-sword-review | archivedate = December 16, 2012 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = June 5, 2018}} | Poly_PS3 = 6/10{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2013/1/8/3852104/black-knight-sword-review-angel-of-death | title = Black Knight Sword review: angel of death (PS3) | first = Philip | last = Kollar | date = January 8, 2013 | website = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] | publisher = [[Vox Media]] | accessdate = June 5, 2018}} | rev1 = ''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'' | rev1_PS3 = {{Rating|2.5|5}}{{cite web | url = http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/video-games/editorials/reviews/10104-Black-Knight-Sword-Review | title = Black Knight Sword Review (PS3) | first = Mike | last = Wehner | date = December 20, 2012 | website = [[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]] | publisher = [[Defy Media]] | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} | rev2 = ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' | rev2_X360 = 6/10{{cite news | url = https://metro.co.uk/2012/12/14/black-knight-sword-review-something-completely-different-3316536/ | title = Black Knight Sword review - something completely different (X360) | first = Roger | last = Hargreaves | date = December 14, 2012 | newspaper = [[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] | publisher = [[DMG Media]] | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} | MC_PS3 = 66/100{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/black-knight-sword | title = Black Knight Sword for PlayStation 3 Reviews | website = [[Metacritic]] | publisher = CBS Interactive}} | MC_X360 = 65/100{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/black-knight-sword | title = Black Knight Sword for Xbox 360 Reviews | website = Metacritic | publisher = CBS Interactive}} }} ''Black Knight Sword'' received "mixed or average reviews" on both platforms according to the [[Review aggregator|review aggregation]] website [[Metacritic]]. Critics praised the game's art style, with ''[[Eurogamer]]'' stating, "Its richest ideas are to be found in the presentation, the aesthetic, the art direction and stage direction." Reviewers often criticized its gameplay, however. While Meristation praised the gameplay, stating, "''Black Knight Sword'' is a good return to the roots of the 16-bit action games, well crafted, with an amazing design",{{cite web | url = http://meristation.as.com/xbox-360/black-knight-sword/analisis-juego/1535833 | title = Black Knight Sword (360) | language = Spanish | first = Pablo González | last = Taboada | date = December 13, 2012 | website = Meristation | accessdate = June 4, 2018}} other reviewers cited the game's difficulty as a point of contention. ''[[Joystiq]]'' wrote, "Yes, [the PSN version's] Normal mode itself is tremendously hard, but not in such a way as to make the struggle seem worth it, or even remotely do-able." {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{moby game|id=/black-knight-sword}} {{Grasshopper Manufacture|state=expanded}} {{Suda 51}} {{Portal bar|Video games|2010s}} [[Category:2012 video games]] [[Category:Dark fantasy video games]] [[Category:Grasshopper Manufacture games]] [[Category:Hack and slash games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Network games]] [[Category:Side-scrolling video games]] [[Category:Unreal Engine games]] [[Category:Video games scored by Akira Yamaoka]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games developed in Hungary]] [[Category:Video games featuring female protagonists]] [[Category:Xbox 360 Live Arcade games]] [[Category:Metroidvania games]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{about|the album|the accompanying short film|Blue Lips (short film)}} {{Infobox album | name = Blue Lips | type = studio | artist = [[Tove Lo]] | cover = Tove Lo - Blue Lips.png | alt = | released = {{Start date|2017|11|17|df=yes}} | recorded = October 2016 – July 2017 | genre = {{hlist|[[Dance-pop]]|[[electropop]]}} | length = 44:24 | label = [[Island Records|Island]] | producer = {{hlist|Choukri Gustmann|[[Alex Hope (songwriter)|Alex Hope]]|[[Jack & Coke]]|[[Lukas Loules|Lulou]]|[[Ali Payami]]|The Struts|Gustav Weber Vernet}} | prev_title = [[Lady Wood]] | prev_year = 2016 | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Extra album cover | header = Alternative cover | type = studio | cover = BlueLipsDeluxeVinylCover.png | caption = 2018 vinyl reissue with ''Lady Wood'' }}{{Singles | name = Blue Lips | type = studio | single1 = [[Disco Tits]] | single1date = 7 September 2017 | single2 = [[Bitches (Tove Lo song)|Bitches]] | single2date = 7 June 2018 }}}} '''''Blue Lips''''' (alternatively titled '''''Blue Lips (Lady Wood Phase II)''''' and stylised as '''''BLUE LIPS [lady wood phase II]''''') is the third studio album by Swedish singer [[Tove Lo]]. It was released on 17 November 2017 by [[Island Records]].{{cite web |last=Blistein |first=Jon |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/tove-lo-embraces-sex-drugs-puppets-in-wild-disco-tits-w507335 |title=Watch Tove Lo's Sexy Road Trip With a Puppet in 'Disco Tits' Video |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=5 October 2017 |accessdate=5 October 2017}} ''Blue Lips'' is considered the second half of a two-piece [[concept album]] that describe "highs, lows and ultimate demise of a relationship."{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/2016/10/31/tove-lo-lady-wood-short-film/|title=Tove Lo's Lady Wood short film previews new music|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|last=Feeny|first=Nolan|date=31 October 2016|accessdate=7 September 2017}} Its chapters "Light Beams" and "Pitch Black" succeed the chapters "Fairy Dust" and "Fire Fade" from her previous album ''[[Lady Wood]]'' (2016).{{cite web |last=Spanos |first=Brittany |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/tove-lo-on-losing-control-exploring-rushes-on-lady-wood-w441207 |title=Tove Lo on Going to Extremes: 'I'm Never as Happy as When I Lose Control' |work=Rolling Stone |date=14 October 2016 |accessdate=22 October 2016}} In addition to the return of songwriter-producers such as The Struts, [[Ali Payami]] and Joe Janiak, the album features new collaborations with [[Alex Hope (songwriter)|Alex Hope]] and [[Lukas Loules|Lulou]], among others. [[Daye Jack]] is the only featured artist on the album. Musically, the album has been described as "sharply conceived [[dance-pop]]" and it is noted to follow the "hypnotizing [[electro-pop]] vein" of the preceding album.{{cite web|url=https://vmagazine.com/article/tove-los-new-album-blue-lips-uncensored-sequel-lady-wood/|title=Tove Lo's New Album 'Blue Lips' Is An Uncensored Sequel to 'Lady Wood'|work=[[V (American magazine)|V]]|author=Jake Viswanath|date=November 17, 2017}} A [[Blue Lips (short film)|short film by the same name]] was released on 19 October 2018 to accompany the album.{{cite web|title=Tove Lo on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/ToveLo/status/1050029212470407168}} ==Background and recording== Tove Lo's previous album, ''[[Lady Wood]]'', was released on 28 October 2016 to positive critical reviews and fair commercial success, with it eventually becoming her highest-charting album in the United States to date. In press interviews in support of the album's release, Tove Lo alluded to another album of thematically similar material slated for release the following year that was tentatively titled ''Lady Wood: Phase II''.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2016/10/28/tove-lo-lady-wood-album/92709012/|title=Swedish singer Tove Lo: 'Don't tell me what I can't say'|work=[[USA Today]]|last=Ryan|first=Patrick|date=28 October 2016|accessdate=7 September 2017}} In early 2017, Tove Lo began the [[Lady Wood Tour]] in further support of the album, and during press interviews she said she was working on new material to be included with the portion that was already recorded during the ''Lady Wood'' sessions.{{cite web|url=http://www.fuse.tv/2017/06/tove-lo-interview-governors-ball-2017-lady-wood-album-sequel-vaginas|title=Governors Ball 2017: Tove Lo Talks 'Lady Wood' Album Sequel & Being Proud of Your Vagina|work=[[Fuse (TV channel)|Fuse]]|last=Gracie|first=Bianca|date=5 June 2017|accessdate=7 September 2017}} The ''Blue Lips'' track "Bitches", originally titled "What I Want for the Night (Bitches)", was previewed through Tove Lo's short film ''[[Fairy Dust (film)|Fairy Dust]]'' in October 2016{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/2016/10/31/tove-lo-lady-wood-short-film/|title=Tove Lo's Lady Wood short film previews new music|work=Entertainment Weekly|last=Feeney|first=Nolan|date=31 October 2016|accessdate=13 November 2017}} and a live version was released through [[Spotify]] in November 2016.{{cite web|title=Spotify Singles by Tove Lo on Spotify|url=https://open.spotify.com/album/6FOhbAW6X74onlLJOTNIjD|website=Spotify|accessdate=13 November 2017}} Tove Lo also previewed the track "Struggle" (then titled "The Struggle") during her performance at the [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]] in April 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/1935431/watch-tove-lo-debut-new-song-the-struggle-at-coachella/video/|title=Watch Tove Lo Debut New Song "The Struggle" At Coachella|work=[[Stereogum]]|last=Rettig|first=James|date=17 April 2017|accessdate=13 November 2017}} During the months leading up to the album's release, Tove Lo said that thematically ''Blue Lips'' would be a "dramatic" and "highly emotional" sister to ''Lady Wood'',{{cite web|url=http://www.papermag.com/swedish-pop-star-tove-lo-on-rocking-coachella-her-dream-collabs-and-fl-2376537617.html|title=Swedish Pop Star Tove Lo on Rocking Coachella, Her Dream Collabs, and Flashing Her Fans|work=[[Paper (magazine)|Paper]]|last=Ward|first=Kat|date=24 April 2017|accessdate=7 September 2017}} and it would have two contrasting chapters: "Light Beams" and "Pitch Black". The album's official title was announced in conjunction with its lead single "[[Disco Tits]]" on 7 September 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.stereogum.com/1961329/tove-lo-disco-tits/music/|title=Tove Lo – "Disco Tits"|work=[[Stereogum]]|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=7 September 2017|accessdate=7 September 2017}} The album's artwork was released on Tove Lo's social media on 31 October 2017. ==Release== Tove Lo began teasing the release of her third studio album since the release of ''[[Lady Wood]]'' in 2016. During January 2017 she suggested that the album would be released in the spring of that year,{{cite web|title=Tove Lo is the no-holds-barred pop misfit we need right now|url=https://www.timeout.com/newyork/music/tove-lo-is-the-no-holds-barred-pop-misfit-we-need-right-now|website=Time Out New York|accessdate=13 November 2017}} but on 31 October 2017 she confirmed that ''Blue Lips'' would be officially released on 17 November 2017.{{cite web|title=BLUE LIPS [lady wood phase II] will be out nov 17. can't wait to share with you|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Ba6xagqAIdr/|website=Instagram|accessdate=31 October 2017}} On the night of the album's release, Tove Lo hosted a release party concert at Elsewhere in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]].{{cite web|title=#BLUELIPS release party Nov 17 @elsewherespace in BKLYN. Can't wait to enter into the phase II era with my NY babes. Tickets on sale now, see you on the dance floor on Friday.|url=https://twitter.com/ToveLo/status/930137982631366661|website=Twitter|accessdate=13 November 2017}} == Singles == The lead single "[[Disco Tits]]" as released on 7 September 2017. It reached #55 in Tove Lo's native Sweden, and topped the United States [[Dance Club Songs]] Chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.sverigetopplistan.se/|title=Sverigetopplistan – Sveriges Officiella Topplista|publisher=[[Sverigetopplistan]]|accessdate=15 September 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/Tove-Lo/chart-history/dance-club-play-songs|title=Tove Lo Chart History|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-06-07}} Tove Lo announced a remix of "[[Bitches (Tove Lo song)|Bitches]]" featuring [[Alma (Finnish singer)|ALMA]], [[Charli XCX]], [[Elliphant]] and [[Icona Pop]] as the second single from ''Blue Lips''.{{Cite news|author=Andrew Trendell|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/tove-lo-bitches-charli-xcx-alma-icona-pop-elliphant-2332749|title=Tove Lo unveils NSFW video for new remix of ‘Bitches’ featuring Charli XCX, ALMA, Icona Pop and Elliphant|date=June 7, 2018|work=[[NME]]|accessdate=June 7, 2018}} It was released on June 7, 2018.{{Citation|title=bitches - Single by Tove Lo, Charli XCX, Icona Pop, Elliphant & ALMA|date=2018-06-07|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/bitches-single/1391556933|language=en-AU|accessdate=2018-06-07}} ==Critical reception== {{Album ratings | MC = 74/100{{cite web Lo Continues Dark Lust Saga on 'Blue Lips' |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=20 November 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}} }} ''Blue Lips'' received generally positive reviews from music critics. At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a normalised rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album has an average score of 74 based on six reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews". ===Year-end lists=== {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders unsortable" |- !Critic/Publication !scope="col" class="unsortable"| List !data-sort-type="number"| Rank !scope="col" class="unsortable"| {{abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- !scope="row" | ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | 20 Best Pop Albums of 2017 | align="center"| 13 | align="center"| {{cite web|last1=Spanos|first1=Brittany|last2=Vozick-Levinson|first2=Simon|last3=Johnston|first3=Maura|last4=Levy|first4=Joe|last5=Hermes|first5=Will|last6=Sheffield|first6=Rob|title=20 Best Pop Albums of 2017|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/20-best-pop-albums-of-2017-w513516/girl-ray-earl-grey-w513533|website=Rolling Stone|accessdate=12 December 2017}} |- !scope="row"|[[:fr:Melty|Melty]] |Best Pop Albums of the Year |{{center|7}} | {{center|{{cite news|url=https://www.melty.fr/taylor-swift-loic-nottet-lorde-les-meilleurs-albums-pop-de-l-annee-a635080.html|title=Taylor Swift, Loïc Nottet, Lorde... For example, "Don't Ask Don't Tell" appears as "dont ask dont tell", and "Disco Tits" as "disco tits". * "Disco Tits" features additional vocals by Fat Max Gsus. ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2017) ! scope="col"| Peak

revision.comment: He was still active in 2009 as the caption of the photo states
revision.text:
{{About||the activist group [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|Sea Shepherd]]'s ship|MY Bob Barker|the prison supply company|Bob Barker Company}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} {{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}} {{Infobox person | name = Bob Barker | image = Bob Barker at WWE crop.jpg | caption = Bob Barker [[List of WWE Raw guest hosts|guest-hosting]] ''[[WWE Raw]]'' on September 7, 2009, at [[Allstate Arena]] in [[Rosemont, Illinois]] | birth_name = Robert William Barker | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1923|12|12|94}} | birth_place = [[Darrington, Washington]], U.S. | occupation = Television personality
Game show host | years_active = 1950–2009 | spouse = {{marriage|Dorothy Jo Gideon|1945|1981|end=d.}} }} '''Robert William Barker''' (born December 12, 1923) is a retired American television [[game show]] [[Master of Ceremonies|host]]. He is known for hosting [[CBS]]'s ''[[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]]'' from 1972 to 2007, making it the longest-running daytime [[game show]] in North American television history. He is also known for hosting ''[[Truth or Consequences]]'' from 1956 to 1974. Born in [[Darrington, Washington]], to modest circumstances, Barker enlisted in the [[United States Navy]] during [[World War II]]. Barker worked part-time in radio while he attended college. In 1950, Barker moved to [[California]] in order to pursue a career in broadcasting. He was given his own radio show, ''The Bob Barker Show'', which ran for the next six years.{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/bob-barker-9542237 |title=Bob Barker Biography - Facts, Birthday, Life Story |publisher=Biography.com |date=December 12, 1923 |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} Barker began his game show career in 1956, hosting ''Truth or Consequences''. From there, he hosted various game shows, as well as the [[Miss Universe]] and [[Miss USA]] pageants from 1967 to 1987, giving him the distinction of being the longest-serving host of these pageants. Eventually, he began hosting ''The Price Is Right'' in 1972. When his wife Dorothy Jo died, Barker became an advocate for [[animal rights]] and of [[animal-rights movement|animal-rights activism]], supporting groups such as the [[United Activists for Animal Rights]] and the [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]]. In 2007, Barker retired from hosting ''The Price Is Right'' after celebrating his 50-year career on television. ==Early life== [[File:Robert (Bob) Barker - South Dakota's Indian Census Roll; April 1, 1930.jpg|thumb|295px|Recorded as Robert Barker in the Indian Census Roll, 1930]] Barker was born on December 12, 1923, in [[Darrington, Washington]], and spent most of his youth on the [[Rosebud Indian Reservation]] in [[Mission, South Dakota]]. The U.S. Indian Census Rolls, 1885–1940, list Barker as an official member of the [[Sioux]] tribe.{{cite web | title = Robert (Bob) Barker - South Dakota's Indian Census Roll April 1, 1930 | url = http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Robert_(Bob)_Barker_-_South_Dakota%27s_Indian_Census_Roll;_April_1,_1930.jpg | accessdate =June 25, 2011}}{{cite web | title = U.S., Indian Census Rolls, 1885-1940 Record for Robert Barker | publisher = ancestry.com | url = http://search.ancestry.com/iexec?htx=View&r=an&dbid=1059&iid=M595_440-0017&fn=Robert&ln=Barker&st=r&ssrc=&pid=2281849 | accessdate =June 25, 2011}}{{cite web | title = U.S. Indian Census Rolls, 1885-1940 about Robert Barker | publisher = ancestry.com | url = http://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?rank=1&new=1&MSAV=0&msT=1&gss=angs-g&gsfn=Robert&gsln=Barker&mswpn__ftp=South+Dakota%2c+USA&mswpn=44&mswpn_PInfo=5-44&msbdy=1923&uidh=qg3&pcat=ROOT_CATEGORY&h=2281849&db=Indian_Schedules&indiv=1 | accessdate =June 25, 2011}} His mother, Matilda ("Tillie") Valandra ({{née}} Matilda Kent Tarleton), was a school teacher; his father, Byron John Barker, was the foreman on the electrical high line through the state of Washington. Barker is 1/8 [[Sioux]].{{cite web | last = Axelrod | first = Laura | title = Book Review: Priceless Memories by Bob Barker with Digby Diehl | publisher = lauraaxelrod.net | url = http://www.lauraaxelrod.net/2009/03/book-review-priceless-memories-by-bob-barker-with-digby-diehl.html | accessdate = October 23, 2014 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151018105421/http://www.lauraaxelrod.net/2009/03/book-review-priceless-memories-by-bob-barker-with-digby-diehl.html | archivedate = October 18, 2015 | df = mdy-all }} While in Washington, his father fell from a tower and sustained an injury which resulted in his death in 1929. Barker has a half-brother, Kent Valandra, from Matilda's subsequent remarriage. In 1931, the family moved to [[Springfield, Missouri]], where Barker graduated from [[Central High School (Springfield, Missouri)|Central High School]] in 1941. Barker attended Drury College (now [[Drury University]]) in Springfield, on a basketball [[athletic scholarship|scholarship]]. He was a member of the Epsilon Beta Chapter of [[Sigma Nu]] [[Fraternities and sororities|fraternity]] at Drury.{{cite web|url=http://www.sigmanu.org/about/famous_sigmanus.php |title=Famous Sigma Nus |publisher=Sigma Nu Fraternity, Inc. |accessdate=July 10, 2015}} On the outbreak of [[World War II]], Barker served in the [[United States Navy]] as a [[fighter pilot]]. However, the war ended before he was assigned to a [[Squadron (aviation)|seagoing squadron]]. After the war, he returned to Drury to finish his education, graduating ''[[summa cum laude]]'' with a degree in [[economics]]. ==Career== ===Broadcasting career=== While attending college in Drury, Barker worked his first "media job", at [[KTTS-FM]] Radio, in Springfield. He and his wife left Springfield and moved to [[Lake Worth, Florida]], and he was news editor and announcer at nearby WWPG 1340 AM in Palm Beach (now WPBR in Lantana).{{cite web|url=http://www.scrippsmedia.com/ktts/news/206929541.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711193249/http://www.scrippsmedia.com/ktts/news/206929541.html |archivedate=July 11, 2015 |title=Bob Barker Shares Story Of Fire While Working At KTTS |publisher=scrippsmedia.com |date=May 10, 2013 |accessdate=July 10, 2015}} In 1950, Barker moved to California in order to pursue a career in broadcasting. He was given his own radio show, ''The Bob Barker Show'', which ran for the next six years from Burbank. He was hosting an audience-participation radio show on [[KNX (AM)]] in [[Los Angeles]] when game show producer [[Ralph Edwards]] happened to be listening and liked Barker's voice and style. ===Game show career=== {{BLP sources section|date=September 2009}} ====''Truth or Consequences'' (1956–1974)==== [[File:Bob Barker 1958 Truth or Consequences.jpg|thumb|Bob Barker in ''Truth or Consequences'', circa 1958]] Barker started hosting ''[[Truth or Consequences]]'' on December 31, 1956, and continued with the program until 1974.{{cite book | title= Total Television | first= Alex | last= McNeil | page = 867 | publisher = (4th edition) [[Penguin Books]] | year = 1996 | isbn=978-0140249163}} The idea was to mix the original quiz element of game shows with wacky stunts. On the show, people had to answer a trivia question correctly (usually an off-the-wall question that no one would be able to answer correctly) before "Beulah the Buzzer" was sounded. If the contestant did not complete the "Truth" portion, there was a "Consequences", usually a zany and embarrassing stunt. If the contestant answered the question, invariably, the question had a second part. In addition, during Barker's run as host, "Barker's Box" was played. Barker's Box was a box with four drawers in it. If a contestant was able to pick all three drawers with money inside before picking the empty drawer, they won a bonus prize. It was on ''Truth or Consequences'' that the salute became his trademark sign-off; he ended each episode with "Bob Barker saying goodbye, and hoping all your consequences are happy ones!"{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} ====''End of the Rainbow'' (1957–1958)==== On December 4, 1957, Barker began hosting a new Ralph Edwards creation, the short-lived ''End of the Rainbow'' for NBC. On this show (similar to Barker's ''Truth or Consequences'' and Edwards' ''[[This Is Your Life]]''), he and co-host Art Baker went out to various places in America and surprised the less-fortunate who helped others when they could barely help themselves. For example, the first episode featured a [[Minneapolis]] grocer who, in return for his community service, was given a complete makeover to his store plus new furniture and appliances for his home. In addition, his landlord (who was in on the surprise) announced that the current month's rent was free and that the grocer's rent would never increase. ====''The Family Game'' (1967)==== In 1967, Barker hosted the short-lived game show ''[[Family Game|The Family Game]]'' for [[Chuck Barris]], where he asked children contestants questions about their families' lives, and the parents had to guess how they answered, similar to ''[[The Newlywed Game]]''. ====''Simon Says'' (1971)==== In 1971, Barker was tapped to host a pilot for NBC entitled ''Simon Says'', which required him to interact with a giant computer called "Simon" in ''[[Let's Make A Deal]]''-style "trades". The pilot was produced by Wesley J. Cox of DUNDAS Productions, and its theme was "The Savers" (the theme used on ''[[The Joker's Wild]]'', which has led some to believe that Cox or DUNDAS was an alias for Jack Barry or Dan Enright, since ''Joker'' used the theme in its original 1968 pilot). There is at least one (somewhat low-quality) clip of the pilot on the video sharing website [[YouTube]].{{YouTube|Mneno-WH_6g}} ====''That's My Line'' (1980–1981)==== In 1980, Barker hosted a series called ''[[That's My Line]]'' for Goodson-Todman. The series was not a game show, but rather a program along the lines of ''[[Real People]]'' and ''[[That's Incredible!]]'' The show's second season in 1981 focused more on unusual stunts, and was cancelled in September. ====''The Price Is Right'' (1972–2007)==== [[File:Bob Barker 1975.jpg|thumb|190px|Bob Barker in 1975]] In early 1972, [[Mark Goodson]] and [[Bill Todman]] began shopping a modernized revival of ''[[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]]'' to stations, with [[Dennis James]] as host. CBS expressed interest in the series, on one condition: instead of James, Barker would be installed as host. After some initial resistance, Barker instead offered to host another upcoming CBS game show, Jack Barry's ''[[The Joker's Wild]]'' (which had difficulty finding a host and was scheduled to debut the same day as ''Price'') to allow James to host ''Price'', but CBS rejected this proposal.{{cite web|last1=Rice|first1=Lynette|title=Bob Barker on saying goodbye to ''The Price Is Right''|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2007/06/08/bob-barker-saying-goodbye-price-right|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=May 19, 2015}} The eventual compromise that was struck led to Barker hosting the daytime ''Price'' on CBS, James hosting the weekly nighttime ''Price'' in syndication, and Jack Barry himself (first on a trial basis, then eventually permanently) hosting ''Joker''. On September 4, 1972, Barker began hosting the CBS revival of ''The Price Is Right''.McNeil, p. 671 In the 35 years of the CBS version, Barker became far more associated with the series than first host [[Bill Cullen]] was with the [[The Price Is Right (1956 US version)|1956–65 original]]. When James' contract for the nighttime ''Price'' expired without being renewed in 1977, Barker assumed hosting duties for three nighttime seasons as well, with the nighttime series eventually ending in 1980. On October 15, 1987, Barker did what other MCs almost never did: renounced hair dye and began wearing his hair gray, which was its natural color by that time.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-07-08/news/tv-514_1_bob-barker | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Susan | last=King | title=Bob Barker Wins the Game of Endurance | date=July 8, 1990}} Fellow hosts [[Monty Hall]], [[Alex Trebek]], and [[Richard Dawson]] did the same in the late 1980s.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} Barker took over the role of [[executive producer]] for the show in 1988, following the death of the original executive producer, [[Frank Wayne]]. In this capacity, Barker created several pricing games, instituted a prohibition on foreign cars and animal-based products (see "Animal rights" below), and launched a prime-time series of specials known as ''[[The Price Is Right $1,000,000 Spectacular]]''. In September 2006, ''The Price Is Right'' marked its 35th consecutive year on the air. It is the longest-running game show of all time in North America, and at the time was the last surviving show in the daytime game show genre, having survived (at the time) twelve years after its last competitor had been canceled. (CBS later revived daytime game shows in 2009.) Overall, in daytime programming (excluding Saturday and Sunday), ''The Price Is Right'' is ranked sixth among the longest-continuing daytime television programs (NBC's ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today]]'' ranks the longest, followed by four daytime soap operas: ''[[Guiding Light]]'', ''[[As the World Turns]]'', ''[[General Hospital]]'', and ''[[Days of Our Lives]]''). It has won its time slot (11:00 a.m. [[North American Eastern Time Zone|Eastern]]) for the past 25 years with its closest competitor (currently [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC's]] ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'') normally getting about half of ''TPIR's'' ratings. {{Wikinews|Bob Barker to retire as host of U.S. gameshow The Price Is Right}} On October 31, 2006, Barker made his announcement that he would retire from ''The Price Is Right'' in June 2007.{{cite news|last=Keveney |first=Bill |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2006-10-31-bob-barker_x.htm?POE=LIFISVA |title=Bob Barker, 82, to retire |work=USA Today |date=November 1, 2006 |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} He taped his final episode on June 6, 2007, with the show airing twice on June 15.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117965636.html?categoryId=14&cs=1|title=Barker's final 'Price' airing June 15|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |first=Josef |last= Adalian|date=May 22, 2007|accessdate=May 24, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014073735/http://variety.com/article/VR1117965636.html?categoryId=14&cs=1|archivedate=October 14, 2007}} The first airing was in the show's normal daytime slot and the second airing was in primetime as the lead-in to the ''Daytime Emmy Awards''. Repeat episodes from Barker's final season continued to air until October 12, 2007. On July 23 it was announced that comedian [[Drew Carey]] would take Barker's place as the new host for the show beginning on October 15, 2007. During Barker's tenure as host, three pricing games were introduced that used his name: Barker's Bargain Bar, Barker's Marker$ and Trader Bob. Of the three, the latter two are not actively played on the show – Trader Bob was retired from the show in 1985, Barker's Marker$ was renamed Make Your Mark following Barker's retirement, and subsequently retired, and Barker's Bargain Bar has been retooled as the Bargain Game after a four-year hiatus between 2008 and 2012. After his retirement, Barker made three return appearances to ''The Price is Right''. He first appeared on the episode that aired on April 16, 2009 to promote his new autobiography, ''Priceless Memories''. He appeared in the Showcase round at the end of the show.{{cite news |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118001621.html?categoryId=14&cs=1 |title=Barker to appear on 'Price Is Right' |author=Steward Levine |accessdate=March 30, 2009 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=March 24, 2009}} Barker made another guest appearance on the show to celebrate his 90th birthday celebration, which aired on December 12, 2013. He announced a contestant for the first time ever on the show, along with one showcase.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/bob-barker-returns-to-the-price-is-right-for-birthday-celebration/|title=Bob Barker returns to "The Price is Right" for birthday celebration |accessdate=December 12, 2013 |work=[[CBS News]] |date=December 12, 2013}} Barker also made a surprise appearance on April 1, 2015 for an April Fools' Day switch where he took Drew's place at the show's intro. He hosted the first one bid and pricing game of that day before handing the hosting duties back to Drew.{{cite news |last=Slane |first=Kevin |date=April 1, 2015 |title=Bob Barker Appeared on ''The Price is Right'' and Everyone Lost Their Minds |url=http://www.bdcwire.com/bob-barker-april-fools/?p1=recent_headline_4_hp |newspaper=Boston Globe |location= |access-date=April 1, 2015 }} He also appeared during the showcase of that episode. ==Personal life== Barker married his high school sweetheart, Dorothy Jo Gideon, on January 12, 1945. They remained married for 36 years until her death, on October 19, 1981, from lung cancer. They had no children, and Barker has not remarried. However, he was involved in a relationship with ''Price'' model [[Dian Parkinson]] from 1989 to 1991, which ended in legal action. ===Health=== Barker has had some minor health problems. Around 1982, he had a [[herniated disc]] and [[sciatica]].{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Greater health problems began in 1991 after he complained of [[Visual perception|vision]] problems while exercising. After a visit to his doctor, he was sent to see a [[neurologist]], who told Barker he had had a mild [[stroke]]. He recovered and went back to work.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} On September 16, 1999, Barker was in [[Washington, D.C.]], to testify before Congress regarding [[Captive elephants|HR 2929: the Captive Elephant Accident Prevention Act]], the proposed legislation that would ban [[elephant]]s from traveling shows (i.e., [[circuses]]). While preparing for the presentation, Barker experienced what he called "clumsiness" in his right hand. He was admitted to [[George Washington University Hospital]] and diagnosed with a partially blocked left [[carotid artery]]. Barker underwent [[carotid endarterectomy]] to remove the blockage. The procedure went well enough that he was able to return to work within the month.{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/1999/09/21/bob-barker-ok-after-3-hr-surgery/ |title=Bob Barker okay after 3-hr surgery |publisher=New York Post |date=September 21, 1999 |accessdate=July 3, 2018 }} Three years later, Barker had two additional health crises after taping the 30th-season finale of ''The Price is Right''. While lying in the sun on May 30, 2002, he experienced a stroke and was hospitalized; six weeks later, on July 11, Barker underwent [[prostate]] surgery. Both hospitalizations occurred at [[George Washington University Hospital]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] Both surgeries were successful.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbs.com/daytime/price/about/justin/rroddy_medicalupdate.shtml |title=Rod Roddy Medical Update |publisher=CBS |date= |accessdate=September 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001000744/http://www.cbs.com/daytime/price/about/justin/rroddy_medicalupdate.shtml |archivedate=October 1, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} Barker has had several mild bouts with [[skin cancer]], a result of his frequent tanning. He consults a dermatologist regularly to make sure any cancers are caught and removed before they spread; they do not currently pose a threat to his life. During a televised interview, Barker told viewers, "I urge anyone who has spent some time in the sun, whether you're doing it now or not, go to a dermatologist once a year."{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/05/02/entertainment/main692422.shtml |title=Bob Barker Has Skin Cancer Again |publisher=CBS News |date=February 11, 2009 |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} On October 20, 2015, two police officers passing Barker's [[Los Angeles]]-area home saw him trip and fall on a sidewalk. They called an ambulance that brought him to [[Cedars-Sinai Medical Center]], where he received stitches for an injured forehead and was released; he also hurt his left knee.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/21/us/bob-barker-hospitalized |title=Bob Barker, TV legend, ex-'Price Is Right' host, recovering after fall| publisher=CNN.com |date=October 22, 2015 |accessdate=April 7, 2017}} Barker slipped and hit his head at home on June 19, 2017. His maid drove him to the emergency room, where he was checked and released. His representative said it was not as serious as his earlier fall.[https://www.aol.com/article/entertainment/2017/06/19/bob-barker-recovering-after-slipping-and-hitting-his-head/22489721/ Kline, J. Bob Barker recovering after slipping and hitting his head at home. AOL.COM, June 19, 2017 11:53AM] ===Lawsuits=== In 1994, former model [[Dian Parkinson]] filed a lawsuit against Barker alleging [[sexual harassment]] following a three-year affair while working on ''[[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]]''. Parkinson, who alleged that she was extorted by threats of firing, later dropped her lawsuit, claiming the stress from the ordeal was damaging her health.[http://www.yuddy.com/celebrity/dian-parkinson/bio Dian Parkinson Bio] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071213073820/http://www.yuddy.com/celebrity/dian-parkinson/bio |date=December 13, 2007 }} In 1995, model [[Holly Hallstrom]] left ''The Price Is Right'' and later filed suit against Barker for wrongful termination and malicious persecution claiming Barker had launched a media attack against her, allegedly stating that she was disruptive to the working atmosphere of the show. Barker dropped his case, but Hallstrom did not, finally ending in [[legal settlement|settlement]] in 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.astrotheme.fr/en/portraits/V5ZG429LgMZf.htm|title=Astrology: Holly Hallstrom, date of birth: 1952/08/24, Horoscope, Astrological Portrait, Dominant Planets, Birth Data, Biography|publisher=astrotheme.fr}} Following their testimonies in Barker's failed lawsuit against Hallstrom, models [[Janice Pennington]] and [[Kathleen Bradley]] were fired, and later received out-of-court financial settlements.[http://www.nerve.com/dispatches/doig/showcaseshowdown Showcase Showdown: Sex and war on the set of America's lustiest game show]. Nerve.com. Accessed December 23, 2010. Director [[Paul Alter]] was removed from the show in 2000. Production assistants Sherrill Paris and Sharon Friem, who were also dismissed at the same time, each sued Barker for wrongful termination, as well as sexual harassment and sex discrimination. Both women ultimately received financial settlements. In October 2007, Deborah Curling, a CBS employee assigned to ''The Price Is Right'', filed a lawsuit against CBS, Bob Barker and ''The Price Is Right'' producers, claiming that she was forced to quit her job after testifying against Barker in a wrongful-termination lawsuit brought by a previous show producer. Curling claimed that she was demoted to an "intolerable work environment" backstage which caused her to leave the job. Curling, who is black, also alleged that the show's producers, including Barker, created a hostile work environment in which black employees and contestants were discriminated against.{{cite news | title="Price Is Right" Employee Sues Bob Barker, Producers | agency=Associated Press | date=October 5, 2007 | url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,299553,00.html | accessdate=October 5, 2007}} A few months later, Barker was removed from the lawsuit, and in September 2009, the lawsuit was dismissed. Curling's attorney stated that he planned to appeal the dismissal of the lawsuit.{{cite web | title=Barker removed from wrongful termination suit | url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/1114222_Barker_removed_from_wrongful_termination_suit }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web | title=Bob Barker, 'Price is Right' lawsuit tossed | publisher=TRH.com | date=September 18, 2009 | url=http://login.vnuemedia.com/hr/content_display/television/news/e3i0d52172227325f28c1048f750ef97812 | accessdate=September 18, 2009}} In January 2012, the California Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal.{{cite web | title=Curling v. CBS Broadcasting Inc. | url=http://www.leagle.com/decision/In%20CACO%2020120124032 | accessdate=October 1, 2014}} ===Animal rights=== Barker became a [[vegetarian]] in 1979. That same year, he began promoting [[animal rights]]. He was named national spokesman for "Be Kind to Animals Week" in May 1985. On [[A&E Network|A&E]]'s ''[[Biography (TV series)|Biography]]'' program, he credited his wife, Dorothy Jo, with causing him to become more aware of animal rights and to become a vegetarian, because she had done so. Bob remarked that Dorothy Jo was way ahead of her time in recognizing the rights of animals and that shortly after her death in October 1981 he took up animal rights in order to keep doing something that she had done. Barker began ending some episodes (later every episode) of ''[[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]]'' with the phrase: "This is Bob Barker reminding you to help control the pet population — have your pets [[Neutering|spayed or neutered]]." After Barker retired, [[Drew Carey]] continued his signature sign-off advocating neutering. Fellow game-show hosts [[Jack Barry (television)|Jack Barry]] and [[Bert Convy]] eventually followed Barker's lead in promoting animal rights on the air.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cbs.com/daytime/price/about/bios/cast_bios_bbarker.shtml |title=CBS Biography for Bob Barker |publisher=CBS |date= |accessdate=September 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321032422/http://www.cbs.com/daytime/price/about/bios/cast_bios_bbarker.shtml |archivedate=March 21, 2008 }} Barker hosted the [[Miss USA]]/[[Miss Universe|Universe]] Pageants from 1967 to 1987. In 1987, he requested the removal of fur prizes and stepped down as host when those in charge of the pageant refused. Barker's '''DJ&T Foundation''', founded in 1994 and named after his late wife and mother, has contributed millions of dollars for animal neutering programs[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117950232.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 Host's passion for pets more bit than bark] – ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' Sunday September 17, 2006 and to fund animal rescue and park facilities all over the United States. He worked closely with [[Betty White]] as an advocate for animal rights.[http://www.christinepalma.com/2007/06/08/bob-barker-host-of-price-is-right-retires-after-50-years/ Bob Barker host of "Price Is Right" retires after 50 years] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211034431/http://www.christinepalma.com/2007/06/08/bob-barker-host-of-price-is-right-retires-after-50-years/ |date=December 11, 2008 }} However, in 2009, reports indicated that Barker threatened to not attend the 2009 Game Show Awards, where he was to receive a lifetime achievement award, because White would be attending. The reason for the conflict, according to the report, was over the proper treatment of an elephant at the Los Angeles Zoo. White instead did not attend and pre-recorded her comments that she was scheduled to make about Mark Goodson.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/05/30/bob-barker-almost-a-no-show-at-game-show-awards-because-of-feud/ |title=Bob Barker almost a no-show at Game Show Awards because of feud with Betty White |publisher=Tvsquad.com |date= |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} In 2004, Barker donated $1 million to [[Columbia University School of Law]] to support the study of animal rights.{{cite web|url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/media_inquiries/news_events/2005_older/2004/nov/bobbarker_gift |title=Columbia Law School: Bob Barker Gives Law School $1 Million for Animal Rights Law |publisher=Law.columbia.edu |date=December 2004 |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} The gift has funded an adjunct professorship in animal rights law at Columbia and helped fund a student clinic in environmental law. Barker also supported [[United Activists for Animal Rights]], and together with the group, publicly accused several media projects and the [[American Humane Association]] of animal mistreatment or the condoning of animal mistreatment, a tactic which resulted in a major lawsuit against him and the group, accusing him of spurious allegations.[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20121207,00.html Speaking Up for 'Abused' Animals, Bob Barker Is Hit with a Lawsuit] – ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', September 18, 1989, Vol. 32, No. 12. In June 2009, Barker wrote Chief Michell Hicks of the [[Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians]] asking that their [[Qualla Boundary|reservation's]] [[bear]] exhibit be closed.{{cite web|url=http://www.wlos.com/shared/newsroom/top_stories/wlos_vid_418.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=June 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728063233/http://www.wlos.com/shared/newsroom/top_stories/wlos_vid_418.shtml |archivedate=July 28, 2011 }} On July 28, 2009, he visited the reservation and saw one of the three zoos, calling the bears' living situation "inhumane". [[PETA]] set up the visit after Barker heard from [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Bill Young]], (R) [[Florida]], whose wife had been "appalled" by what she saw. Annette Tarnowski, the tribe's attorney general, said a federal inspector had found nothing wrong in May 2009 at two of the zoos, and that the tribe had dealt with the few violations at the third. Hicks made no promises and threatened to ban PETA if they made more trouble.{{cite news|url=http://www.citizen-times.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090729/NEWS01/907290316/1009/news01 |title=Bob Barker, PETA call for release of Cherokee zoo animals|first=Jon|last=Ostendorff|work=[[Asheville Citizen-Times]]|date=July 29, 2009|accessdate=July 29, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In January 2010, [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]] announced that it had secretly purchased and outfitted a ship to interdict Japanese whaling operations in the [[Southern Ocean]] using $5,000,000 provided by Barker. The ship was then named the [[MY Bob Barker|MY ''Bob Barker'']], and its existence was first revealed when it helped discover the location of the Japanese whaling fleet.{{cite news |url=http://www.seashepherd.org/news-and-media/news-100105-1.html |title=The Time is Right for Bob Barker to Rescue the Whales |accessdate=January 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721235545/http://www.seashepherd.org/news-and-media/news-100105-1.html |archivedate=July 21, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} In 2010, Barker began funding the cost of a helicopter, named the Nancy Burnet (after the president of United Activists for Animal Rights); the helicopter accompanies the society's fleet.{{cite news |url=http://www.seashepherd.org/who-we-are/the-fleet.html |title=Sea Shepherd Fleet |accessdate=January 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081103110127/http://www.seashepherd.org/who-we-are/the-fleet.html |archivedate=November 3, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} In March 2010, PETA announced that it received a $2.5 million donation from Barker to help establish a new office called the Bob Barker Building in Los Angeles.{{cite news|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_PETA_BOB_BARKER?SITE=NHPOR&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315211403/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_PETA_BOB_BARKER?SITE=NHPOR&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|dead-url=yes|archive-date=March 15, 2010|title=Barker donates $2.5 million to create PETA offices|accessdate=March 10, 2010|df=mdy-all}} PETA officially opened the Bob Barker Building on Sunset Boulevard in 2012.George Pennachio, [http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/story?section=news/entertainment&id=8573763 "Bob Barker Building Will Be PETA's West Coast Hub"], KABC-TV, March 8, 2012. The Grand Opening was attended by [[Christian Serratos]], [[Stephanie Pratt]], [[Moby]], [[Kate del Castillo]], [[Sasha Grey]], [[Renee Olstead]], [[Fivel Stewart]], [[Diane Warren]], and [[Allisyn Ashley Arm]].[http://www.peta.org/blog/la-office-launch/ PETA’s New Bob Barker Building Opens in L.A.] at PETA.org[http://www.peta2.com/blog/petas-bob-barker-building-opens-in-los-angeles/ PETA's Bob Barker Building Opens in Los Angeles!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817193953/http://www.peta2.com/blog/petas-bob-barker-building-opens-in-los-angeles/ |date=August 17, 2016 }} at Peta2.com ==Film and other TV appearances== *In 1996, Barker played himself in the [[Adam Sandler]] comedy ''[[Happy Gilmore]]''. In one scene, Barker beats up Gilmore after an altercation arising from their teaming up in a Pro-Am Golf Tournament.[http://www.allmoviephoto.com/photo/bob_barker_adam_sandler_happy_gilmore_001.htm Movie Photos: Bob Barker and Adam Sandler in Happy Gilmore – 1996]{{Dead link|date=February 2012}} In 2007, during a CBS prime-time special commemorating Barker's career, the fight scene from ''Happy Gilmore'' was shown, after which, Sandler made a surprise appearance on stage to read a poem paying tribute to Barker.{{cite web|title=Ode to Bob Barker with Adam Sandler|url=http://www.metatube.com/en/videos/6516/Ode-to-Bob-Barker-with-Adam-Sandler/|accessdate=3 November 2017|date=10 December 2007}} In 2015, during [[Comedy Central|Comedy Central's]] "Night of Too Many Stars" benefit show for autism, Barker and Sandler reunited for a video featuring the two of them in follow-up fight at the hospital, which ends with both of them dying and going to heaven.{{cite web|title=Adam Sandler vs. Bob Barker - Uncensored - Night of Too Many Stars {{!}} Comedy Central|url=http://www.cc.com/video-clips/hs7ja6/night-of-too-many-stars-adam-sandler-vs--bob-barker---uncensored|website=Comedy Central|accessdate=3 November 2017}} *In the late 1990s, Barker played the father of [[Mel Harris]]' character on a few episodes of the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Something So Right (TV series)|Something So Right]]''. *He appeared in two animated television series as himself: in the ''[[Futurama]]'' episode "[[The Lesser of Two Evils]]" in 2000, followed by the ''[[Family Guy]]'' episodes "[[Screwed the Pooch]]" in 2001, "[[The Fat Guy Strangler]]" in 2005, and "[[Tales of a Third Grade Nothing]]" in 2008. *Barker was a semi-regular panelist on the game shows ''[[Tattletales]]'' (with wife Dorothy Jo) and ''[[Match Game]]''. Barker sat in [[Richard Dawson]]'s former place during the first week of Dawson's permanent absence from ''Match Game''.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/98/Bob-Barker.html |title=Filmreference Bob Barker Biography (1923–) |publisher=Filmreference.com |date= |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} Barker also played on ''The Price Is Right'' team against ''[[The Young and the Restless]]'' on ''[[Family Feud]]'' in 1991 and 1993. *Barker co-hosted CBS' coverage of the [[Rose Parade]] from Pasadena, California for several years during the 1970s and 1980s. *He created and hosted ''The Bob Barker Fun and Games Show'', which was a combination of stunt participation in the style of ''[[Truth or Consequences]]'' and pricing games such as ''The Price Is Right'' in which he traveled throughout the United States and Canada in various arenas and venues. Events took place from 1978 to 1986. *In the 1970s, he was the host of the annual/biennial ''[[Pillsbury Bake-Off]]'' (the bake-off occurred every two years starting in 1976). In 1978, he was the first host to have a male category champ. *He was a guest host on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' in 1966, when he was a regular on NBC hosting ''Truth or Consequences''. *He appeared on ''[[Bonanza]]'', playing a character named Mort in the 1960 episode "Denver McKee". *He has appeared on various talk shows such as: ''[[Dinah!]]'', ''[[Larry King Live]]'', ''[[The Arsenio Hall Show]]'', ''[[Crook & Chase]]'', ''[[Donny & Marie (1998 TV series)|Donny & Marie]]'', ''[[The Rosie O'Donnell Show]]'', ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'', ''[[The Wayne Brady Show]]'', the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', and ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]''. *Barker also made cameo appearances on ''[[The Nanny]]'', ''[[The Bold and the Beautiful]]'' in 2002 and 2014, ''[[Yes, Dear]]'', and ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'' with announcer [[Rich Fields]] in 2007. *About one year after retirement, Barker appeared in a [[public service announcement]] promoting the transition to [[digital television in the United States]]. The advertisement was produced under the first proposed date of February 16, 2009 for the transition.{{YouTube|0h56EHBWrtg}}{{dead link|date=September 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dtvanswers.com/dtv_30spots.html |title=DTV Action Spots |publisher=DTV Answers |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} *On September 7, 2009, Barker was a special guest host for ''[[WWE Raw]]'' (called "The Price is Raw") in [[Rosemont, Illinois]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pwnewsnow.com/news.php?subaction=showfull&id=1251732972&archive=&start_from=&ucat=6 |title=Bob Barker to Host WWE Raw on September 7 in Chicago |publisher=Pwnewsnow.com |date=August 31, 2009 |accessdate=September 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305065626/http://www.pwnewsnow.com/news.php?subaction=showfull&id=1251732972&archive=&start_from=&ucat=6 |archivedate=March 5, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} *Barker agreed to be a rotating guest co-host on ''The Huckabee Show'', a daily TV talk show hosted by [[Mike Huckabee]]. Barker first appeared on the show July 29, 2010.{{cite web |last=Weprin |first=Alex |url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/generalities/mike_huckabee_talks_syndicated_show_as_bob_barker_comes_on_down_168762.asp |title=Mike Huckabee Talks Syndicated Show as Bob Barker 'Comes On Down' |publisher=Mediabistro.com |date=July 26, 2010 |accessdate=September 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730105355/http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/generalities/mike_huckabee_talks_syndicated_show_as_bob_barker_comes_on_down_168762.asp |archivedate=July 30, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} *Barker appeared in a commercial for [[State Farm Insurance]]'s "Magic Jingle" campaign, where he made "a new car!" appear for a woman whose previous car was totaled by a giant concrete cylinder.{{YouTube|7pOC29Dv894|State Farm® Commercial "Magic Jingle Bob Barker"}}. State Farm's official [[YouTube]] account. Retrieved February 25, 2011. *Barker filmed a TV advertisement endorsing [[David Jolly]], a candidate for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] nomination for the [[Florida's 13th congressional district special election, 2014|special election]] in his Congressional district.{{cite news| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/12/12/bob-barker-says-the-choice-is-right/?hpt=hp_t3 | work=CNN | title=Bob Barker says 'the choice is right' | date=December 12, 2013}} *Barker voiced the character Bob Barnacle, a snail business owner on the [[Nickelodeon]] animated series ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]''.{{cite news| url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/39-spongebob-squarepants-39-sneak-peek-bob-1277495686053942.html?soc_src=mail&soc_trk=ma | work=Yahoo | title='SpongeBob SquarePants' Sneak Peek: Bob Barker Comes to the (Snail) Rescue | date=October 14, 2015}} ==Awards and honors== *19-time [[Emmy Award]] winner **14 individual awards for [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Game Show Host|Outstanding Game Show work=Time|date=May 25, 2007}} *[[NAB Broadcasting Hall of Fame]] (class of 2008).{{cite web|url=http://www.tvtechnology.com/pages/s.0096/t.13007.html|title=Broadcasters Tell Bob Barker to 'Come on Down!' |accessdate=April 21, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516195130/http://www.tvtechnology.com/pages/s.0096/t.13007.html |archivedate=May 16, 2008 }}{{cite web web|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/05/30/bob-barker-almost-a-no-show-at-game-show-awards-because-of-feud |title=Bob Barker almost a no-show at Game Show Awards because of feud with Betty White |publisher=Tvsquad.com |date= |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} *2009 [[WWE]] [[Slammy Award]] for Best ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'' Guest Host. ==Autobiography== Bob Barker has written his autobiography, assisted by former ''L.A. Times'' book review editor Digby Diehl, titled ''Priceless Memories''. It was published on April 6, 2009, and features stories from his early life as well as stories and experiences in the 50 years of his television career.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Priceless-Memories-Digby-Diehl/dp/1600245536 |title=Priceless Memories (9781600245534): Digby Diehl, Bob Barker: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=September 4, 2012}} It was also then reported that Barker would appear on ''The Price Is Right'' to promote his book. His initial appearance was scheduled for the March 2, 2009, taping. However, the taping was postponed until March 25, due to host Drew Carey's bout with [[pneumonia]]. The episode aired on April 16, during which Barker appeared during the [[The Showcase|Showcases]] to promote the book. Carey stated in an interview that the show stopped taping for over an hour as the crowd continued to give Barker a standing ovation, and to allow the audience to ask questions about what Barker was
